The Voyage of the Nkhwazi

Blue Horizons: The Voyage of the Nkhwazi

'The Voyage of the Nkhwazi' is the second expedition undertaken by Jack and Angus. They travelled to Lake Malawi, first revealed to European eyes in 1846 and later explored by David Livingstone in 1859, the 3rd largest lake in Africa. They commissioned the construction of a local wooden fishing boat - the HMS Nkhwazi and planned to navigate the entirety of the lake. They set course to travel from the southern tip of the Lake to the northern Coast along the isolated east coast. Local knowledge was key to the success of the expedition so they enlisted the help of Charles Gilson, a Malawian who could speak Chichewe, Yao and English (the former two being spoken along much of the eastern coast). The hardship of the trip as well as the proximity of either working alongside each other on the boat or sleeping together in a tent meant that a firm friendship sprung up between Charles and the boys. HMS Nkhwazi (Chichewe for Eagle) was propelled by 10 hour days of rowing on oars with rope bindings acting in lieu of rollicks. However, when the wind was blowing in the right direction (which was disappointingly infrequent) they were able to indeed fly like an Nkhwazi as they fashioned a sail from potatoe sack cloth and a mast from a tree trunk.

The Lake proved a tough adversary as the trio of boys battled storms and 10ft waves as their small vessel braved the elements. The adventure also suffered from a chronic lack of food as settlements were so few and far between and the villages they did come across often didn’t have the resources to furnish the boys with provisions. This meant that one meal a day of rice and chomba (a type of fish of the lake) and the odd chapatti for a snack was the only sustenance available for the gruelling days of exertion. Yet the real aim of the trip was to understand and document the lives of the local fishermen of the lake. Often operating out of dugout canoes, or out of larger boats at night with kerosene lamps to help attract fish, these men of the lake eke out an incredibly hard existence: theirs is a world on the edge of humanity’s frontiers with nature. Alongside these rugged lifestyles was the lake – truly magnificent in its beauty. Often the water was so clear the boys could see to a depth of 30 metres down. The lake was framed by the magnificent Livingstone Mountains rising straight up out of the lake and at dusk the huge mass of water would often transform into an inky mirror reflecting the oranges pinks, blues and yellows that only an African sky can give.

But all was not always tranquil in paradise, on the Tanzanian border Angus, Jack and Charles were woken up in the middle of the night surrounded by villagers and some men wielding rifles. The locals had called in the police fearful that this boat landing with two English boys and a Malawian was something to do with the oil dispute between Malawi and Tanzania. Luckily the situation was quickly diffused. Perseverance and determination saw the boys to the top of the lake. The adventure was again filmed and is currently in the post production stage.
